The probability of a marriageable couple in the first two seats is 2⋅815⋅7142 \cdot\frac{8}{15} \cdot \frac{7}{14}2⋅158​⋅147​. Note that 815\frac{8}{15}158​ is also the expected number of marriageable couples in the first two seats. Our sam calculation can applies to any adjacent pair so we can get the average number of marriageable adjacent pairs by taking the number of adjacent pairs and multiplying by the expected value of each adjacent pair being marriageable: 14⋅815=11215≈7.4714 \cdot \frac{8}{15} = \frac{112}{15} \approx 7.4714⋅158​=15112​≈7.47. Then the expected number of marriageable couples is just under half of the people present.

Moving on to a more general case, when we can bbb elements of one type and mmm of another randomly arranged in a line, the expected number of unlike adjacent elements is

(m+b+1)[2⋅bm(m+b)(m+b−1)](m+b+1) \left[2\cdot \frac{bm}{(m+b)(m+b-1)}\right](m+b+1)[2⋅(m+b)(m+b−1)bm​]

which can be shown easily by going through the same process we used for our specific case.

Day Twelve: July 3

Come back later for today’s problems!

Problem 1. Two players bet on the number of rolls of the total of two standard six faced dice. Player AAA bets tha a sum of 121212 will occur first and player BBB bets that two consecutive 777’s will be rolled before that. What is the probability that AAA will win? Solution. This question can be solved either through conditional probability or a Markov chain approach. I’ve opted for a Markov chain since it’s much more straightforward and easily illustrated. Below is the Markov diagram for this problem. I’ve chosen to denote ∅\empty∅ the event of rolling for the first time. Since every time we roll something other than a 777 or a 121212 we essentially reset, each state gives us a certain probability of returning to our original state. It’s worth noting that after rolling the first 777 there is still a nontrivial probability for BBB to win as 121212 can still be rolled in the next round.

Then we have the following system of equations to solve:

p∅=136+2936p∅+16p7p7=136+2936p∅\begin{aligned} p_\empty &= \tfrac{1}{36} + \tfrac{29}{36}p_\empty + \tfrac{1}{6}p_7\\ p_7 &= \tfrac{1}{36} + \tfrac{29}{36}p_\empty \end{aligned}p∅​p7​​=361​+3629​p∅​+61​p7​=361​+3629​p∅​​

Noting that p7,7=0p_{7,7} = 0p7,7​=0 and p12=1p_{12} = 1p12​=1, solving gives us that p∅=713p_\empty = \frac{7}{13}p∅​=137​. Then, player AAA is slightly favored to win over player BBB in their bet.

Problem 2. There are 51 ants on a square with side length of 1. If you have a glass with a radius of 1/7, can you put your glass at a position on the square to guarantee that the glass encompasses at least 3 ants? Solution. We can do this by creating 252525 sub-squares and using the pidgeonhole principle to conclude that ones of these sub-squares must have at least 333 ants. In creating these 252525 sub-squares, we want them to cover the entirety of the original 1×11\times 11×1 square so each of these smaller squares will have a 15\frac{1}{5}51​ side length. Note that a sub-square with side length 15\frac{1}{5}51​ has diagonal length 215≈0.282\sqrt{2}\frac{1}{5} \approx 0.2822​51​≈0.282. Meanwhile, the radius 17\frac{1}{7}71​ glass cup has a diameter of 27≈0.285\frac{2}{7} \approx 0.28572​≈0.285, so any sub-square can be inscribed within the glass. Then, we simply need to choose the sub-square with the most ants and place our glass carefully to cover at least three ants.

Problem 3. The probability you’ll see a falling star in the sky over the course of one hour is 0.44. What’s the probability you’ll see one over half an hour? Solution. This is a past Citadel interview question that I’ve seen variants of at other companies. We can assume that each half hour is independent from the other regarding falling star appearances. Then, the probability of not seeing a shooting star in either half-hour intervals is 0.560.560.56. Let ppp be the probability that we see a shooting star in a thirty minute interval. Then we have

(1−p)(1−p)=0.56(1-p)(1-p) = 0.56(1−p)(1−p)=0.56

Solving gives us p≈0.25p \approx 0.25p≈0.25. This question is meant to be solved mentally so I didn’t include and pen or paper for it. For taking the square root of 0.560.560.56, I did a linear approximation based off of 0.49\sqrt{0.49}0.49​ and 0.64\sqrt{0.64}0.64​.

Problem 4. You are given two ropes that when lit burn in one hour. Which one of the following time periods CANNOT be measured with your ropes? a) 50 min b) 30 min c) 25 min d) 35 min. Solution. The only time period I can’t think of a solution to is 505050 min. The key to this problem is realizing that we can burn the rope wherever we want. It’s easy to finding 303030 minutes by burning a single rope on both ends. We can burn 353535 by first measuring 303030 minutes. Then, we measure 555 additional minutes by burning the second rope on both ends and 555 additional times in the middle. This process will create two ropes, all of which burn on both of their ends. If any of these ropes burn out fully, all we need to do is light one of the other 555 ropes in the middle. Keep doing this proccess and you’ll have an additional 555 minutes measured. To measure 252525 minutes, we can burn one of the ropes on both ends and once in the middle. If one of the two ropes formed by the burning burns out, then light the other sub-rope in the middle, making sure the rope is still burning in 444 places. This ensures that the first rope will finish burning in 101010 minutes. Then, we need only light the second rope on both ends and two times in the middle. This ensures the second rope burns at 666 places, and so we’ll measure 101010 additional minutes that way.

Problem 5. You have three cards, each labeled nnn, n+1n+1n+1, n+2n+2n+2, and you don’t know nnn. All cards start facing down so you can’t see them. You flip one card. If you choose to “stay”, you get that card’s value. If you don’t “stay”, then you flip another card. Again, choose to “stay” (and keep the 2nd card’s value) or flip the final card and keep the final card’s value. Design the optimal strategy to maximize the value of the card that you choose and find the expectation of that value. Solution. Note that your expected value will be at least nnn. Making our decision on draw 111 ensures we have no information and making our decision of draw 333 presents us with no choice. Then it makes sense for us to make our decision on round 222. Since we have the ability to draw once again after round 222, our decision is simply to take what we drew or draw again. I will refer to each draw iii as did_idi​. Then, if
d2−d1=−2:d_2 - d_1 = -2:d2​−d1​=−2: we have the sequence n+2,n,n+1n+2, n, n+1n+2,n,n+1 so we choose to draw again for ev n+1n+1n+1
d2−d1=2:d_2 - d_1 = 2:d2​−d1​=2: we have the sequence n,n+2,n+1n, n+2, n+1n,n+2,n+1 so we stay for ev n+2n+2n+2
d2−d1=1:d_2 - d_1 = 1:d2​−d1​=1: we either go up 111 (n,n+1,n+2n,n+1, n+2n,n+1,n+2) or down 222 (n+1,n+2,nn+1, n+2, nn+1,n+2,n) so we choose to stay for ev n+1.5n + 1.5n+1.5 d2−d1=−1:d_2 - d_1 = -1:d2​−d1​=−1: we either go up 222 (n+1,n,n+2n+1, n, n+2n+1,n,n+2) or down 111 (n+2,n+1,nn+2, n+1, nn+2,n+1,n) so we choose to draw again for ev n+1n+1n+1 Using this strategy, we combine our total expected value:

E[X]=36(n+1)+16(n+2)+26(n+1.5)=n+44\mathbb{E}[X] = \tfrac{3}{6}(n+1) + \tfrac{1}{6}(n+2) + \tfrac{2}{6}(n+1.5) = n+ \tfrac{4}{4}E[X]=63​(n+1)+61​(n+2)+62​(n+1.5)=n+44​

My optimal strategy is to draw the first two cards and determine whether to draw again with the thought process above with expected value n+43n + \frac{4}{3}n+34​. Putting it more simply, if the second draw is higher than the first, then stay, and if not, then draw again.

Week Two Review:

This week I focused on working through more of A Practical Guide, and starting to pull general probability question from resources. i’ve done a bit of market-making practice behind the scenes and am still figuring out the best way of going about that. I didn’t get to review as many topics as I had hoped to and next week I hope to work on some more programming/staticstics questions as recruiting season begins.

Here are this week’s list of resources:

  • A Practical Guide to Quantitative Finance Interviews (Ch 2, 4)
  • Fifty Challenging Problems in Probability
  • eFinancialCareers Past Interview Questions
  • Confidence Intervals
  • MIT Quant Finance Presentation
  • Citadel Glassdoor Questions

item.title: A Working List of Probability Questions: Week 1
item.description: An ongoing series of probability/statistics problems and brain teasers.
item.content:encoded:
In Preparation For Quantitative Trading Interviews
June 21, 2020 | Updated June 28, 2020

This series is mostly for my own self-documentation purposes as I prepare for recruiting at the end of summer. I’ll be updating this page with 5 new problems/brain teasers and solutions every day to keep myself accountable. These problems will come from a variety of sources, including A Practical Guide to Quantitative Finance Interviews, Math Stack Exchange, and UC Berkeley’s EECS 126 course notes. You can skip to my week one review here or navigate to a specific day using the legend below. Thanks for tuning in!

Day 1   |   Day 2   |   Day 3   |   Day 4   |   Day 5   |   Day 6   |   Day 7  

Day One: June 21

Today’s problems are relatively simple as I spent a while figuring out the LaTeX formatting on websites.

Problem 1. What is the expected number of tosses to get three consecutive heads when flipping a fair coin? Solution. Let E[3]\mathbb{E}[3]E[3] denote the expected number of rolls for 333 consecutive heads. If we start rolling and roll a tail first, which has probability 12\frac{1}{2}21​, then the expected number of tosses will be E[3]+1\mathbb{E}[3] + 1E[3]+1. If we roll a head then a tail, which has probability 14\frac{1}{4}41​, then the expected number will be E[3]+2\mathbb{E}[3] + 2E[3]+2. If we roll 2 heads then a tail with probability 18\frac{1}{8}81​ then expected value is E[3]+3\mathbb{E}[3] + 3E[3]+3. Finally if we roll 333 heads consecutively, which has probability 18\frac{1}{8}81​, then E[3]=3\mathbb{E}[3] = 3E[3]=3. Combining these together, we have

E[3]=12(E[3]+1)+14(E[3]+2)+18(E[3]+3)+18(3)\mathbb{E}[3] = \frac{1}{2}(\mathbb{E}[3] + 1) + \frac{1}{4}(\mathbb{E}[3] + 2) + \frac{1}{8}(\mathbb{E}[3] + 3) + \frac{1}{8}(3)E[3]=21​(E[3]+1)+41​(E[3]+2)+81​(E[3]+3)+81​(3)

Solving this equation gives E[3]=14\mathbb{E}[3] = 14E[3]=14. We can extend this to find the expected number of rolls for nnn consecutive heads to get E[n]\mathbb{E}[n]E[n]:

E[n]=12(E[n]+1)+14(E[n]+2)+⋯+12n(E[n]+n)+12n(n)\mathbb{E}[n] = \frac{1}{2}(\mathbb{E}[n] + 1) + \frac{1}{4}(\mathbb{E}[n] + 2) + \cdots + \frac{1}{2^n}(\mathbb{E}[n] + n) + \frac{1}{2^n}(n)E[n]=21​(E[n]+1)+41​(E[n]+2)+⋯+2n1​(E[n]+n)+2n1​(n)

Solving for this in general gives us the formula E[n]=2(2n−1)\mathbb{E}[n] = 2(2^n - 1)E[n]=2(2n−1). A number of other solutions of this type of problem can be found here.

Problem 2. Suppose there are five pirates with 100100100 pieces of gold who are voting on splitting up the gold. The most senior pirate will propose a way to distribute the gold and requires 50%50\%50% of the votes in order to pass his proposal. If he receives less than 50%50\%50% of the votes then he will be killed and the process will begin with the next most senior pirate. How will the gold coins be divided? Solution. Let’s label each pirate in ascending order based on seniority, so pirate 555 will be most senior and 111 will be least senior. Building this up from the two pirate case: Pirate 2 can safely propose he take all 100100100 gold pieces as he constitutes 50%50\%50% of the votes. Then Pirate 1 receives nothing.

Moving on to the three pirate case—Pirate 3 knows that if his plan is voted down, then Pirate 2 can take all 100100100 coins and Pirate 1 will receive nothing. All he needs to do is give Pirate 1 one coin to secure his vote. Adding a fourth pirate, Pirate 4 knows that if his plan is voted down, then Pirate 2 will get nothing. Then all he needs to do is propose to offer Pirate 1 one coin and keep the remaining 99. Now considering all five pirates, Pirate 5 knows that if his plan is voted down, Pirate 1 and Pirate 3 will receive nothing. Then all he needs to do is offer 1 gold coin each to Pirate 1 and Pirate 3, keeping the 98 coins.

We can extend this to any number nnn pirates (so long as n<=200n<= 200n<=200). If nnn is odd, the most senior pirate will offer Pirates 1,3,…,n−21, 3, \dots, n - 21,3,…,n−2 each one coin and keep the remainder for himself. If nnn is even, then he will offer Pirates 2,4,…,n−22, 4, \dots, n-22,4,…,n−2 one coin each and keep the remainder.

Problem 3. For a best of 3 set tennis match, would you bet on it finishing in two sets or three sets given that probabilty of winning a set is constant? Solution. Let p=P(player 1 wins)p = P(\text{player 1 wins})p=P(player 1 wins) and q=P(player 2 wins)q = P(\text{player 2 wins})q=P(player 2 wins). To win in two sets, we can have player 1 or player 2 win two consecutive sets, giving a total probability of p2+q2p^2 + q^2p2+q2. In order for the match to end in three sets, one player must win 2 sets (assume thats its player 1) and the other one set. This corresponds with a probability of 2pq2pq2pq. Note that (p−q)2≥0(p - q)^2 \geq 0(p−q)2≥0, implying that p2+q2≥2pqp^2 + q^2 \geq 2pqp2+q2≥2pq, so I would bet on the match finishing in two sets.

Problem 4. Your break a stick of length 1 at two points uniformly. What is the probability that the three resulting pieces can form a triangle? Solution. A triangle is possible to form so long as one piece is not longer than the sum of the other two (one side >12> \frac{1}{2}>21​) and the difference between two pieces is not longer than the third. Consider the midpoint MMM of the original stick: if both cuts are made on the same side of MMM (probability 12)\frac{1}{2})21​), then one side will have length greater than 12\frac{1}{2}21​ and a triangle is not possible. Let’s say we break the stick at two points xxx and yyy with x<yx < yx<y and xxx and yyy are on different side of MMM. There is probability 12\frac{1}{2}21​ that xxx is farther left on it half of the stick than yyy is right on its half or the vice versa. In this case, we can’t form a triangle either because the difference between two sides will be longer than the third. Then only (1−12)⋅(1−12)=14(1 - \frac{1}{2}) \cdot ( 1 - \frac{1}{2}) = \frac{1}{4}(1−21​)⋅(1−21​)=41​ of breaks can form a triangle (my justification of this seems a bit shady and I’ll work on a more analytical solution another time).

Problem 5. Consider a game where there are two blue balls and two red balls in a bag. Each ball is removed from the bag without replacement and if you guess the color of the ball correctly you earn a dollar. How much would you pay to play this game? Solution. On your first draw you have a 24\frac{2}{4}42​ chance of guessing correctly. On the second draw, you have a 23\frac{2}{3}32​ chance of guessing correctly so long as you guess the color opposite of the first ball. By the third ball, either you have selected two balls of the same color with probability 13\frac{1}{3}31​ or you selected two balls of different color with probability 23\frac{2}{3}32​. In the first case you are guaranteed to know the colors of the next ball and in the second you have a 50%50\%50% chance of guessing the next ball correctly. Finally, the probability of guessing correctly on the last ball is 111. Then calculating the expected value of the game from our individual draws:

E[x]=(24⋅1)+(23⋅1)+(13⋅1+23⋅12⋅1)+1=176\mathbb{E}[x] = (\frac{2}{4}\cdot 1) + (\frac{2}{3}\cdot 1) + (\frac{1}{3} \cdot 1 + \frac{2}{3}\cdot\frac{1}{2} \cdot 1) + 1 = \frac{17}{6}E[x]=(42​⋅1)+(32​⋅1)+(31​⋅1+32​⋅21​⋅1)+1=617​

So I would pay $176\frac{17}{6}617​ to play this game.

Day Two: June 22

Today’s problems focus on stochastic processes and Markov chains. A couple of these problems come from David Aldous’s STAT 150 page. I also came across a pretty sick compilation of different resources this morning.

Problem 1. A calculating machine uses the digits 000 and 111 and transmits one of these digits through several stages. At every stage, there is a probability ppp that the digit will be changed with it leaves and probability q=1−pq = 1 - pq=1−p that it will not. Suppose the machine starts at state 0. What is the probability that the machine will display the correct digit after 2 stages? Solution. We can identify the Markov chain for this problem as below:

010qp1pq\begin{matrix} & 0 & 1\\ 0 & q & p\\ 1 & p & q \end{matrix}01​0qp​1pq​

which produces the transition matrix

P=(qppq)P= \begin{pmatrix} q & p\\ p & q \end{pmatrix}P=(qp​pq​)

We are interested in finding the probability that the state remains in state 0 after two time periods, which is indexed by the (1,1)(1,1)(1,1)-entry of P2P^2P2. Then,

P2=(qppq)(qppq)=(q2+p22qp2pqp2+q2)P^2 = \begin{pmatrix} q & p\\ p & q \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} q & p\\ p & q \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} q^2 + p^2 & 2qp\\ 2pq & p^2 + q^2 \end{pmatrix}P2=(qp​pq​)(qp​pq​)=(q2+p22pq​2qpp2+q2​)

and our desired probability is q2+p2q^2 + p^2q2+p2.

Problem 2. A transmitter is sending binary code (+ and - signals) that must pass through three relay signals before being sent on to the receiver. At eachrelay station, there is a 25%25\%25% chance that the signal will be reversed. Suppose +++ signals make up 60%60\%60% of the messages sent. If a +++ signal is received, what is the probability that a +++ was sent? Solution. This was a problem in the notes of my statistics class last semester and was solved using a tree diagram. I decided to take a stochastic approach:

Let AAA be the event that a +++ was transmitted and BBB be the event that +++ is received after it passes through the third relay. We’re interested in finding P(A ∣ B)P(A \, | \, B)P(A∣B), which by Bayes’ Theorem can be written as

P(A ∣ B)=P(B ∣ A)P(A)P(B)=P(B ∣ A)P(A)P(B ∣ A)P(A)+P(B ∣ Ac)P(Ac)P(A \, | \, B) = \frac{P(B\, | \, A)P(A)}{P(B)} = \frac{P(B\, | \, A)P(A)}{P(B \, | \, A)P(A) + P(B \, | \, A^c)P(A^c)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(B∣A)P(A)​=P(B∣A)P(A)+P(B∣Ac)P(Ac)P(B∣A)P(A)​

Note that AcA^cAc is the event that a −-− was transmitted. Let’s consider the Markov chain for this problem:

+−+0.750.25−0.250.75\begin{matrix} & + & -\\ + & 0.75 & 0.25\\ - & 0.25 & 0.75 \end{matrix}+−​+0.750.25​−0.250.75​

giving us the transition matrix

P=(0.750.250.250.75)→P3=(0.56250.43650.43650.5625)P= \begin{pmatrix} 0.75 & 0.25\\ 0.25 & 0.75 \end{pmatrix} \to P^3 = \begin{pmatrix} 0.5625 & 0.4365\\ 0.4365 & 0.5625 \end{pmatrix}P=(0.750.25​0.250.75​)→P3=(0.56250.4365​0.43650.5625​)

We can see that P(B ∣ A)=P1,13=0.5625P(B\, | \, A) = P^3_{1,1} = 0.5625P(B∣A)=P1,13​=0.5625 and P(B ∣ Ac)=P2,13=0.4365P(B \, | \, A^c) = P^3_{2,1} = 0.4365P(B∣Ac)=P2,13​=0.4365. Then, we have

P(A ∣ B)=0.5625⋅0.60.5625⋅0.6+0.4365⋅0.4=0.6585P(A \, | \, B) = \frac{0.5625 \cdot 0.6}{0.5625 \cdot 0.6 + 0.4365 \cdot 0.4} = 0.6585P(A∣B)=0.5625⋅0.6+0.4365⋅0.40.5625⋅0.6​=0.6585

Problem 3. Consider a Markov chain with two states: 1 and 2. If p1,2=ap_{1,2} = ap1,2​=a and p2,1=bp_{2,1} = bp2,1​=b. For which values of aaa and bbb do we have an absorbing Markov chain? Solution. An absorbing Markov chain is one in which every state can reach a state where, once entered, cannot be left. Our transition matrix looks something like this:

P=(?ab?)P= \begin{pmatrix} ? & a\\ b & ?\\ \end{pmatrix}P=(?b​a?​)

aaa and bbb are the probabilities of state 111 changing to 222 and vice versa. In order for a state to remain constant between time periods, we must have at least one of aaa or bbb be 0 so that upon reaching one of the states, we will leave it.

Problem 4. A Markov chain with the state space {1,2,3}\{1, 2, 3\}{1,2,3} has the transition matrix

P=(1/31/31/301/21/3001)P= \begin{pmatrix} 1/3 & 1/3 & 1/3\\ 0 & 1/2 & 1/3\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}P=⎝⎜⎛​1/300​1/31/20​1/31/31​⎠⎟⎞​

Starting from each state, find the expected time until absorption occurs. Solution. Clearly, absorption happens at state 3. Let E[i]\mathbb{E}[i]E[i] denote the expected time to reach state 333 from i=1,2,3i = 1, 2, 3i=1,2,3. Then, we have

E[1]=1+13E[1]+13E[2]+13E[3]E[2]=1+12E[2]+12E[3]E[3]=0\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[1] &= 1 + \frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}[1] + \frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}[2] + \frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}[3]\\ \mathbb{E}[2] &= 1 + \frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}[2] + \frac{1}{2}\mathbb{E}[3]\\ \mathbb{E}[3] &= 0 \end{aligned}E[1]E[2]E[3]​=1+31​E[1]+31​E[2]+31​E[3]=1+21​E[2]+21​E[3]=0​

Walking through the case of E[1]\mathbb{E}[1]E[1], we get the recursion in the following manner: if we go forward one time period, then there is a 13\frac{1}{3}31​ chance that we are still at state 111 and our expected time is now 1+E[2]1 + \mathbb{E}[2]1+E[2]. Similarly, we have a 13\frac{1}{3}31​ chance of being at state 222 or 333 respectively, which brings us to E[1]=1+13E[1]+13E[2]+13E[3]\mathbb{E}[1] = 1 + \frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}[1] + \frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}[2] + \frac{1}{3}\mathbb{E}[3]E[1]=1+31​E[1]+31​E[2]+31​E[3].

Solving these equations gives us E[i]={5/2if i=12if i=20if i=3\mathbb{E}[i] = \begin{cases} 5/2 & \text{if } i = 1\\ 2 & \text{if } i = 2\\ 0 & \text{if } i =3 \end{cases}E[i]=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​5/220​if i=1if i=2if i=3​

Problem 5. A group of quants wants to determine their average salary but want to do so such that no person has access to anyone else’s salaray. Can they accomplish this, and, if so, how? Solution. I got a bit lazy typesetting math equations so I picked a brain teaser for the last problem. The quants can do this by having the first quant taking a random number and adding his salary to it and passing that number onto the second quant. Then each subsequent quant will add their salary to the sum and tell the number to the next quant. Finally, the first quant removes the random number they chose and divides by the number of total quants for the average salary.

Day Three: June 23

I threw in some statistics questions for today’s problems in addition to the usual bunch.

Problem 1. There are N lions and 1 sheep in a field. All the lions really want to eat the sheep, but the problem is that if a lion eats a sheep, it becomes a sheep. A lion would rather stay a lion than be eaten by another lion. There is no other way for a lion to die than to become a sheep and then be eaten. When is it safe for any lion to eat? Solution. Let’s consider this similarly to Problem 2 of Day 1. If there is one lion, then it can happily eat the sheep. If there are two lions, no lion would eat the sheep for fear of getting eaten by the other lion. If there are three lions, then a lion eating the sheep would reduce us to the two lion scenario, in which no lion would eat the sheep. We can continue on this train of thought for any number NNN and conclude that the sheep will be eaten when NNN is odd. I actually think this problem is actually quite similar to the game of Nim or other impartial combinatorial games in the sense that we’re thinking in terms of a recursion.

Problem 2. You draw cards from a deck without replacement. What is the expected number of cards you draw before you get an ace? Solution. I had to refer to Stack Exchange for this question.You can find the solution here. I was tempted to use μx\mu_xμx​ for a negative binomial distribution but then I realized that we’re drawing without replacement. Let DDD be the r.v. that represents the number of draws before we draw an ace and assign each of the non-ace cards in the deck a number between 111 and 484848. Then we can define the random indicator variable Xi=1X_i = 1Xi​=1 if the card with label iii was drawn before any ace and 000 otherwise. Then, we have that

D=X1+X2+⋯+X48D = X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_{48}D=X1​+X2​+⋯+X48​

From linearity of expectation, we have

E[D]=E[X1+X2+⋯X48]=E[X1]+E[X2]+⋯+E[X48]\mathbb{E}[D] = \mathbb{E}[X_1 + X_2 + \cdots X_{48}] = \mathbb{E}[X_1] + \mathbb{E}[X_2] + \cdots + \mathbb{E}[X_{48}]E[D]=E[X1​+X2​+⋯X48​]=E[X1​]+E[X2​]+⋯+E[X48​]

Let’s consider P(X1=1)P(X_1 =1)P(X1​=1). If we look card 111 along with the 444 aces, it’s pretty simple to see that P(X1=1)=15P(X_1 = 1) = \frac{1}{5}P(X1​=1)=51​. It follows that E[X1]=15\mathbb{E}[X_1] = \frac{1}{5}E[X1​]=51​. Symmetry guarantees that all the XiX_iXi​ have the same distribution so P(Xi=1)=P(Xj=1)P(X_i = 1) = P(X_j = 1)P(Xi​=1)=P(Xj​=1) for all i,j∈[1,…,48]i,j\in[1,\dots, 48]i,j∈[1,…,48]. Then each E[Xi]=15\mathbb{E}[X_i] = \frac{1}{5}E[Xi​]=51​ and E[D]=485\mathbb{E}[D] = \frac{48}{5}E[D]=548​.

Problem 3. You roll a die up to three times. You can decide to stop and choose the number on the die (where the number is your payoff) during each roll. What’s your strategy? Solution. Trading firms often ask these types of questions, where you have to devise an optimal strategy to a game they provide you with. If we work backwards from the end of the game, we know that the expected value of the roll is 72\frac{7}{2}27​. Then, for our second to last roll, it makes sense to reroll if we rolled a 1,2,31,2,31,2,3, and just keep the money and quit if we rolled a 4,5,64, 5, 64,5,6. Then, the expected value of our last two rolls is 12(1+2+3)+12⋅72=4.25\frac{1}{2}(1 + 2 + 3) + \frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{7}{2} = 4.2521​(1+2+3)+21​⋅27​=4.25 (it should make sense why we multiply each EV by 12)\frac{1}{2})21​). Using similar logic to before it makes sense to reroll if we rolled a 1,2,3,41,2,3,41,2,3,4 and keep the money if we rolled a 555 or 666. Then, our strategy is to roll once if we roll a 555 or a 666, reroll otherwise. When rerolling, we’ll keep anything 444 and beyond and reroll our final time otherwise.

Problem 4. A hat contains 100100100 coins, 999999 of them are guaranteed to be fair and 111 that has a 12\frac{1}{2}21​ chance to be double-headed. A coin is randomly chosen at random and flipped 777 times. If it landed heads each time what is the probability that one of the coins is double-headed? Solution. Let’s use Bayes’ Theorem for this question. Let AAA be the event that one of the 100100100 coins is double-headed and BBB be the event that a randomly chose coin lands heads on all 777 flips. We’re interested in finding P(A ∣ B)P(A \, | \, B)P(A∣B). Then,

  • P(A)=12P(A) = \frac{1}{2}P(A)=21​
  • P(Ac)=12P(A^c) = \frac{1}{2}P(Ac)=21​
  • P(B ∣ A)=P( all head flips given unfair coin)=1100+127⋅99100P(B \, | \, A) = P( \text{ all head flips given unfair coin}) = \frac{1}{100} + \frac{1}{2^7}\cdot \frac{99}{100}P(B∣A)=P( all head flips given unfair coin)=1001​+271​⋅10099​
  • P(B ∣ Ac)=P( all head flips given no unfair coin)=127P(B \, | \, A^c) = P( \text{ all head flips given no unfair coin}) = \frac{1}{2^7}P(B∣Ac)=P( all head flips given no unfair coin)=271​

The third bullet point can be solved for by breaking down the components of the probability of rolling all 777 heads in the case of having a guaranteed rigged coin, which is 1100⋅1+127⋅99100\frac{1}{100}\cdot 1 + \frac{1}{2^7}\cdot \frac{99}{100}1001​⋅1+271​⋅10099​. Then we have

P(A ∣ B)=(1100+127⋅99100)⋅12(1100+127⋅99100)12+127⋅12=0.3194P(A \, | \, B) = \frac{(\frac{1}{100} + \frac{1}{2^7}\cdot \frac{99}{100})\cdot \frac{1}{2}}{(\frac{1}{100} + \frac{1}{2^7}\cdot \frac{99}{100})\frac{1}{2} + \frac{1}{2^7}\cdot\frac{1}{2}} = 0.3194P(A∣B)=(1001​+271​⋅10099​)21​+271​⋅21​(1001​+271​⋅10099​)⋅21​​=0.3194

So if we roll 7 heads in a row, there is a 32%32\%32% chance that there is an unfair coin in the bunch.

Problem 5. Let X,Y∼N(0,1)X, Y \sim N(0,1)X,Y∼N(0,1) be i.i.d. random variables. What is the probability that X>3YX > 3YX>3Y? Solution. This is a pretty simple problem that I’m using as statistics review. Lets define Z:=X−3YZ := X - 3YZ:=X−3Y. Then we simply need to find P(Z>0)P(Z > 0)P(Z>0). We know that ZZZ is normally distributed as it’s a linear combination of standard normal variables so we only need to find the mean and standard deviation in order to find P(Z>0)P(Z > 0)P(Z>0). Note that

E[Z]=E[X]−3E[Y]=0\mathbb{E}[Z] = \mathbb{E}[X] - 3\mathbb{E}[Y] = 0E[Z]=E[X]−3E[Y]=0

Also,

σ(Z)=σ(X−3Y)=σ(X)+(−3)2σ(Z)=10\sigma(Z) = \sigma(X-3Y) = \sigma(X) + (-3)^2\sigma(Z) = 10σ(Z)=σ(X−3Y)=σ(X)+(−3)2σ(Z)=10

Note that since ZZZ is normally distributed about 000, we technically don’t even need σ(Z)\sigma(Z)σ(Z) since P(Z>0)=12P(Z >0) = \frac{1}{2}P(Z>0)=21​ for Z∼N(0,σ)Z \sim N(0, \sigma)Z∼N(0,σ). Then, P(X>3Y)=12P(X > 3Y) = \frac{1}{2}P(X>3Y)=21​.

Day Four: June 24

I didn’t get to this until pretty late this evening so I did some relatively simple questions for today.

Problem 1. In unprofitable times corporations sometimes suspend dividend payments. Suppose that after a dividend has been paid the next one will be paid with probability 0.90.90.9, while after a dividend is suspended the next one will be suspended with probability 0.6. In the long run what is the fraction of dividends that will be paid? Solution. This is another Markov chain problem so we’ll tackle it like we have before. We can call the two states of this chain State 1: “dividend paid” and State 2: “dividend suspended”. We’re provided that p1,1=0.9p_{1,1} = 0.9p1,1​=0.9 and p2,2=0.6p_{2,2} = 0.6p2,2​=0.6, which implies that p1,2=0.1p_{1,2} = 0.1p1,2​=0.1 and p2,1=0.4p_{2,1} = 0.4p2,1​=0.4. This gives us the transition matrix

P=(0.90.10.60.4)P = \begin{pmatrix} 0.9 & 0.1 \\ 0.6 & 0.4 \end{pmatrix}P=(0.90.6​0.10.4​)

Let π\piπ be the stationary distribution for our Markov chain. In the steady state,

[π1π2]=[π1π2](0.90.10.60.4)\begin{bmatrix} \pi_1 & \pi_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \pi_1 & \pi_2 \end{bmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 0.9 & 0.1 \\ 0.6 & 0.4 \end{pmatrix}[π1​​π2​​]=[π1​​π2​​](0.90.6​0.10.4​)

Then, 0.9π1+0.6π2=π10.9 \pi_1 + 0.6\pi_2 = \pi_10.9π1​+0.6π2​=π1​ and 0.1π1+0.4π2=π20.1\pi_1 + 0.4\pi_2 =\pi_20.1π1​+0.4π2​=π2​. Note also the π1+π2=1\pi_1 + \pi_2 = 1π1​+π2​=1 be definition. Then, solving this system of linear equations gives us that π1=0.8\pi_1 = 0.8π1​=0.8 and π2=0.2\pi_2 = 0.2π2​=0.2 and

π=[π1π2]=[0.80.2]\pi = \begin{bmatrix} \pi_1 & \pi_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0.8 & 0.2 \end{bmatrix}π=[π1​​π2​​]=[0.8​0.2​]

so 80%80\%80% of dividends will be paid.

Problem 2. If you repeatedly flip a fair coin. What is the expected number of flips you need to do in order to get a head immediately followed by a tail? Solution. We know that we’ll end with HTHTHT so let’s think about the tosses we make before this happens. If we roll a heads on our first try, then we have to roll only heads until we roll our final HTHTHT. For this reason, if there are mmm tosses before HTHTHT, then it has to be of the form TkHm−kT^kH^{m-k}TkHm−k where k=0,1,…,mk = 0,1, \dots, mk=0,1,…,m. Then let XXX be a random variable that describes the number of tosses until we get TTT. We can flip TTT on our first try (p=12p = \frac{1}{2}p=21​), or we could flip heads first and we’d effectively start the process over again (p=12p = \frac{1}{2}p=21​). Then,

E[X]=12⋅1+12(1+E[X])\mathbb{E}[X] = \frac{1}{2}\cdot 1 + \frac{1}{2}(1 + \mathbb{E}[X])E[X]=21​⋅1+21​(1+E[X])

Solving this gives us E[X]=2\mathbb{E}[X] = 2E[X]=2. Now define YYY is the random variable that describes the number of tosses until we get our first HTHTHT. We can either roll a tails on our first try (p=12p=\frac{1}{2}p=21​) and making it so that we have to start over again, or we can roll heads on our first try (p=12p = \frac{1}{2}p=21​), and all we need to do now is roll at TTT, whose EV we just modeled with XXX. Then,

E[Y]=12(1+E[Y])+12(1+E[X])\mathbb{E}[Y] = \frac{1}{2}(1 + \mathbb{E}[Y]) + \frac{1}{2}(1 + \mathbb{E}[X])E[Y]=21​(1+E[Y])+21​(1+E[X])

We can plug in E[x]=2\mathbb{E}[x] = 2E[x]=2 and find that E[Y]=4\mathbb{E}[Y] = 4E[Y]=4! Other solutions to this can be found here.

Problem 3. Let XXX be an r.v. such that E[X2]<∞\mathbb{E}[X^2] < \inftyE[X2]<∞. What constant ccc minimizes E[(X−c)2]\mathbb{E}[(X-c)^2]E[(X−c)2]? Solution. I thought that this would be a difficult problem but then I realized that it was extremely simple. Taking the derivative with respect to ccc gives us

ddcE[(X−c)2]=ddcE[X2−2cX+c2]=E[−2X+2c]=−2E[X]+2c\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dc}\mathbb{E}[(X-c)^2] &= \frac{d}{dc}\mathbb{E}[X^2 - 2cX + c^2] = \mathbb{E}[-2X + 2c] \\ &= -2\mathbb{E}[X] + 2c \end{aligned}dcd​E[(X−c)2]​=dcd​E[X2−2cX+c2]=E[−2X+2c]=−2E[X]+2c​

Setting this equal to 000 makes it pretty clear that c=E[X]c = \mathbb{E}[X]c=E[X] minimizes the expression. You could also solve for this by finding the XXX that minimizes the the expression by differenting with respect to XXX and get the same conclusion but the question specified finding a ccc value. Also, it never hurts to plug this back in and make sure that it is actually a minimum.

Problem 4. What is the expected number of rolls of a fair die needed to get all six numbers? Solution. This was a nice brush-up on geometric distributions. It takes one roll in order to roll out first number. After our first roll, the number of rolls until a second number is rolled is geometrically distributed with success probability p=56p = \frac{5}{6}p=65​. Since μX=1p\mu_X = \frac{1}{p}μX​=p1​ for a geometric distribution, the expected number of rolls until a second number is rolled is 56\frac{5}{6}65​. Continuing in this fashion, the number if rolls before each additional unique number geometrically distributed with probability p=n6p = \frac{n}{6}p=6n​ where nnn is the number of remaining numbers to be rolled. Then,

E[6]=∑i=166i=14.7\mathbb{E}[6] = \sum_{i = 1}^6 \frac{6}{i} = 14.7E[6]=i=1∑6​i6​=14.7

We can extend this further and say that for an nnn-sided die,

E[n]=n∑i=11i\mathbb{E}[n] = n\sum_{i=1}\frac{1}{i}E[n]=ni=1∑​i1​

where

Problem 5. You are on a game show, and there are 3 doors. Two of the doors conceal something worthless, and one door conceals a valuable prize. The game show host, Monty Hall, knows where the prize is. He lets you pick a door, then he opens one of the remaining two doors to reveal something worthless. He then offers you the chance to switch doors. Should you? Solution. This is the Monty Hall Problem. Lets call the doors A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C. If you chose AAA, you have p=13p =\frac{1}{3}p=31​ of guessing the prize, and p=23p = \frac{2}{3}p=32​ of guessing incorrectly. This probability of AAA being correct does not change after the host offers to let you switch after he uncovers one of the other doors (lets say BBB). In allowing you to switch doors, the host is offering you the option to bet on or against whether your first guess was right with p=13p = \frac{1}{3}p=31​ or that it was wrong p=23p= \frac{2}{3}p=32​. In essence, when you choose door AAA there a 23\frac{2}{3}32​ chance that the prize door is either between doors BBB or CCC. This doesn’t change when you open up door BBB to see nothing in it—instead it now means that there is a 23\frac{2}{3}32​ chance that door CCC holds the prize so its better for you to switch. This intuitively makes sense as you’re more likely to bet on a team that has won a game than a team that has played no games (without overanalyzing the specific players and other dynamics of course).

Day Five: June 25

Today’s problems focus on betting games and review of probability distributions.

Problem 1. You play a game where you toss two fair coins in the air and win $1 each time you toss. However, if you have tossed 2 heads at least once, and 2 tails at least once, you lose all your winnings and the game ends. You can also choose to stop playing at anytime. What’s your strategy? Solution. I pulled this problem from stack exchange so you can find some solutions here. Solution 1 on this page derives the solution in a cleaner manner than the solution my friend and I came up with for this.

Our solution: note that it takes at least 2 tosses in order to get HHHHHH and TTTTTT. Then, after we roll our first bad event we have probability 14\frac{1}{4}41​ to lose everything and probability 34\frac{3}{4}43​ to win an additional dollar. Coin tosses are independent so each kthk^{th}kth toss we make after our first bad toss, we have probability (34)k(\frac{3}{4})^k(43​)k of gaining an additional kkk dollars and 1−(34)k1 -(\frac{3}{4})^k1−(43​)k of losing the whole thing. So if we get our first bad toss on toss nnn (by which we have acquired nnn dollars), our expected value for n+kn+kn+k is E[n+k]=(34)k(n+k)\mathbb{E}[n+k] = (\frac{3}{4})^k(n+k)E[n+k]=(43​)k(n+k). To find the optimal time to stop tossing, we need to find the boundary of E[n+k]≤E[n+k+1]\mathbb{E}[n+k] \leq \mathbb{E}[n+k+1]E[n+k]≤E[n+k+1]. That is,

(34)k(n+k)≤(34)k+1(n+k+1)4(n+k)≤3(n+k+1)4n+4k≤3n+3k+3n+k≤3\begin{aligned} (\tfrac{3}{4})^k(n+k) &\leq (\tfrac{3}{4})^{k+1}(n+k+1)\\ 4(n+k) &\leq 3(n+k+1)\\ 4n + 4k &\leq 3 n + 3k + 3\\ n+ k &\leq 3 \end{aligned}(43​)k(n+k)4(n+k)4n+4kn+k​≤(43​)k+1(n+k+1)≤3(n+k+1)≤3n+3k+3≤3​

Note that it’s not always optimal to stop at a total number of rolls ≤3\leq 3≤3. The whole premise of this question revolves around the first bad toss. So if n<3n < 3n<3 (our first bad toss is on toss 1 or 2), we should keep tossing until we’ve tossed 3 times. Otherwise, we should just take our earnings and end the game.

Problem 2. A room of 100 people put their business cards in a hat, then each person randomly draws a business card. What’s the expected number of people who draw their own business card? Solution. Each person has a 1100\frac{1}{100}1001​ chance of drawing their particular name, assuming that everyone draws at the same time. Let XiX_iXi​ be a Bernoulli r.v. with success being person iii drawing their own card. Then, P(Xi=1)=1nP(X_i = 1) = \frac{1}{n}P(Xi​=1)=n1​ from our first observation. It follows that

E[Xi]=∑x∈Rxp(x)=∑x=01xp(x)=0⋅99100+1⋅1100=1100\mathbb{E}[X_i] = \sum_{x \in \mathbb{R}}xp(x) = \sum_{x=0}^1 xp(x) = 0 \cdot \frac{99}{100} + 1 \cdot \frac{1}{100} = \frac{1}{100}E[Xi​]=x∈R∑​xp(x)=x=0∑1​xp(x)=0⋅10099​+1⋅1001​=1001​

Then,

E[X1+⋯+X100]=E[X1]+⋯+E[X100]=n(1n)=1\mathbb{E}[X_1 +\cdots + X_{100}] = \mathbb{E}[X_1] + \cdots + \mathbb{E}[X_{100}] = n(\tfrac{1}{n}) = 1E[X1​+⋯+X100​]=E[X1​]+⋯+E[X100​]=n(n1​)=1

so we expect 111 person to draw their own name. Note that 100100100 is not a special number or anything—if we replace every instance of 100100100 with nnn in our argument, we observe that our EV is still 111 person.

Problem 3. There are 100100100 noodles in a soup bowl you are eating. You are blindfolded and told to take the ends of some noodles and connect them (each end is chose with equal probability). You do this until there are no more free ends. What is the expected number of circles created in this fashion? Solution. This is actually be solved in a stochastic manner. Let f(n)f(n)f(n) be a random variable that describes the number of circles that are made from connecting noodles. Starting from n=1n=1n=1 noodle, you must connect the two ends together, forming E[f(1)]=1\mathbb{E}[f(1)] = 1E[f(1)]=1 circle. For n=2n=2n=2 noodles, there are 4 ends and you must make 2 connections, forming (42)=6\binom{4}{2} = 6(24​)=6 possible connections. Of these, 222 connections will connect the same ends of the same noodle together, giving us 111 noodle and 111 circle. The other four combinations give us a single noodle. Notice that we’re only doing so much as to connect two of the ends, which brings us to a n=1n=1n=1 case. Then the expected number of circles for n=2n=2n=2 is

E[f(2)]=23(1+E[f(1)])+46E[f(1)]\mathbb{E}[f(2)] = \tfrac{2}{3}(1 + \mathbb{E}[f(1)]) + \tfrac{4}{6}\mathbb{E}[f(1)]E[f(2)]=32​(1+E[f(1)])+64​E[f(1)]

Solving this gives us that E[f(2)]=43=1+13\mathbb{E}[f(2)] = \frac{4}{3} = 1 + \frac{1}{3}E[f(2)]=34​=1+31​. Moving on to n=3n=3n=3, we have (62)=15\binom{6}{2} = 15(26​)=15 choices for connections. Of these, 333 choices will yield 111 circle and 222 noodles and the other 121212 will simply yield 222 noodles. Then, we have

E[f(3)]=315(E[1+f(2)])+1215E[f(2)]\mathbb{E}[f(3)] = \tfrac{3}{15}(\mathbb{E}[1 + f(2)]) + \tfrac{12}{15}\mathbb{E}[f(2)]E[f(3)]=153​(E[1+f(2)])+1512​E[f(2)]

Solving this yields E[f(3)]=2315=1+13+15\mathbb{E}[f(3)] = \frac{23}{15} = 1 + \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{5}E[f(3)]=1523​=1+31​+51​. There’s a pretty clear pattern that’s starting to appear. If we extend it to nnn noodles in general, we have that

E[f(n)]=1+13+15+⋯+12n−1=∑k=1n12k−1\mathbb{E}[f(n)] = 1 + \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{5} + \cdots + \frac{1}{2n-1} = \sum_{k = 1}^n \frac{1}{2k -1}E[f(n)]=1+31​+51​+⋯+2n−11​=k=1∑n​2k−11​

Plugging n=100n=100n=100 gives us E[100]≈3.28\mathbb{E}[100] \approx 3.28E[100]≈3.28 (I cheated a bit and used a calculator to find this sum).

Problem 4. Two archers shoot at a target. The distance of each shot from the center of the target is uniformly distributed from 0 to 1, independently of the other shot. What is the PDF (probability density function) of the distance from the center for the losing shot? Solution. Let XXX be the distance from the center of the shot by Archer 1 and YYY be that of Archer 2. Let Z=max⁡{X,Y}Z = \max\{X,Y\}Z=max{X,Y} be the distance from the center of the losing shot. As XXX and YYY are uniformly distributed over [0,1][0,1][0,1], we have that for all z∈[0,1]z\in[0,1]z∈[0,1],

P(X≤z)=P(Y≤z)=z−01−0=zP(X\leq z) = P(Y\leq z) = \frac{z - 0}{1 - 0} = zP(X≤z)=P(Y≤z)=1−0z−0​=z

Then, as XXX and YYY are independent,

FZ(z)=P(max⁡{X,Y}≤z)=P(X≤z , Y≤Z)=P(X≤z)P(Y≤z)=z2\begin{aligned} F_Z(z) &= P(\max\{X,Y\}\leq z) = P(X \leq z \, , \, Y \leq Z)\\ &= P(X \leq z)P(Y \leq z) = z^2 \end{aligned}FZ​(z)​=P(max{X,Y}≤z)=P(X≤z,Y≤Z)=P(X≤z)P(Y≤z)=z2​

When we differentiate we then get the pdf of ZZZ

fZ(z)={2z if z∈[0,1]0 otherwisef_Z(z) = \begin{cases} 2z& \text{ if } z\in[0,1]\\ 0& \text{ otherwise} \end{cases}fZ​(z)={2z0​ if z∈[0,1] otherwise​

This is an interesting problem that I haven’t seen before. I’ve seen another form of the question that asks for the pdf of the winning shot, which is a bit more elusive as ZZZ would be defined as min⁡{X,Y}\min\{X, Y\}min{X,Y} and it wouldnt be clear that we could use the P(X,Y≤z)P(X,Y \leq z)P(X,Y≤z) since the minimum requires only one of them to satisfy the condition.

Problem 5. Let X1,…XnX_1, \dots X_nX1​,…Xn​ be independent random variables uniformly distributed on [0,1][0,1][0,1]. Find P(X1+⋯+Xn≤1)P(X_1 + \cdots + X_n \leq 1)P(X1​+⋯+Xn​≤1)? Solution. Like Problem 333, I’m going to try to start from the n=1n=1n=1 case and try to build up a solution. Clearly, P(X≤1)=1P(X \leq 1) = 1P(X≤1)=1 by definition. P(X1+X2≤1)P(X_1 + X_2 \leq 1)P(X1​+X2​≤1) is the probability that X1X_1X1​ and X2X_2X2​, distributed over the unit square, lie on or below the line that separates the lower left and upper right triangles so P(X1+X2≤1)=12=12!P(X_1 + X_2 \leq 1) = \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{2!}P(X1​+X2​≤1)=21​=2!1​. Moving on to n=3n =3n=3, P(X1+X2+X3)P(X_1 + X_2 + X_3)P(X1​+X2​+X3​) describes the probability that the set of points in the unit cube all lie in the bottom-left-front triangular pyramid (probability 16)=13!\frac{1}{6}) = \frac{1}{3!}61​)=3!1​. Again, a bit of a pattern is showing up: it seems like P(X1+⋯+Xn)=1n!P(X_1 + \cdots + X_n) = \frac{1}{n!}P(X1​+⋯+Xn​)=n!1​. We can confirm this with induction of a more general case, that for 0≤t≤10 \leq t \leq 10≤t≤1

P(X1+⋯+Xn≤t)=tnn!P(X_1 + \cdots + X_n \leq t) = \frac{t^n}{n!}P(X1​+⋯+Xn​≤t)=n!tn​

For simplicity sake, I’ll call Sn:=X1+X2+⋯+XnS_n := X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_nSn​:=X1​+X2​+⋯+Xn​. We’ve already proved the base case earlier in our solution. Then suppose our assumption holds for nnn, then for n+1n+1n+1:

P(Sn+1≤t)=∫01P(Sn+x≤t)f(x) dx=∫0t(t−x)nn! dx=tn+1(n+1)!\begin{aligned} P(S_{n+1}\leq t) &= \int_0^1P(S_n + x \leq t)f(x)\,dx = \int_0^t\frac{(t-x)^n}{n!}\, dx \\ &= \frac{t^{n+1}}{(n+1)!} \end{aligned}P(Sn+1​≤t)​=∫01​P(Sn​+x≤t)f(x)dx=∫0t​n!(t−x)n​dx=(n+1)!tn+1​​

and thus our claim is proved by induction. This last part does require a bit of massaging but should be clear after applying a bit of calculus/analysis. Then, it follows that P(Sn≤1)=1n!P(S_n \leq 1) = \frac{1}{n!}P(Sn​≤1)=n!1​

Day Six: June 26

Most of the questions today come from A Practical Guide to Quantitative Finance Interviews and past interview questions.

Problem 1. Bond AAA will default next year with p=0.5p = 0.5p=0.5 and bond BBB will default next year with p=0.3p= 0.3p=0.3. What is the range of probability that at least one bond defaults and what is the range of their correlation? Solution. The upper bound on the the probability of at least one bond defaulting takes place when AAA defaulting and BBB defaulting are mutually exclusive, in which case,

P(A or B defaults)=P(A)+P(B)=0.5+0.3=0.8P(\text{A or B defaults}) = P(A) + P(B) = 0.5 + 0.3 = 0.8P(A or B defaults)=P(A)+P(B)=0.5+0.3=0.8

For the lower bound, we consider the case when AAA and BBB are completely dependent events. Then,

P(A or B defaults)=max⁡{A,B}=0.5P(\text{A or B defaults}) = \max\{A, B\} = 0.5P(A or B defaults)=max{A,B}=0.5

Then P(A or B defaults)∈[0.5,0.8]P(\text{A or B defaults}) \in [0.5, 0.8]P(A or B defaults)∈[0.5,0.8]. To calculate the correlation between AAA and BBB, let IAI_AIA​ and IBI_BIB​ be indicator variables for the events that AAA and BBB default and let ρ\rhoρ be their correlation. We have that E[IA]=0.5\mathbb{E}[I_A] = 0.5E[IA​]=0.5 and E[IB]=0.3\mathbb{E}[I_B] = 0.3E[IB​]=0.3. Since AAA and BBB are Bernouli random variables, we have that σIA=pA(1−pA)=0.52=0.25\sigma_{I_A} = p_A(1 - p_A) = 0.5^2 = 0.25σIA​​=pA​(1−pA​)=0.52=0.25. Similarly, σIB=0.21\sigma_{I_B} = 0.21σIB​​=0.21. We have that

P(A or B defaults)=E[IA]+E[IB]−E[IAIB]=E[IA]+E[IB]−(E[IA]E[IB]−Cov(IA,IB))=0.5+0.3−(0.5⋅0.3−ρσIAσIB)=0.65−0.212ρ\begin{aligned} P(\text{A or B defaults}) &= \mathbb{E}[I_A] + \mathbb{E}[I_B] - \mathbb{E}[I_AI_B]\\ &= \mathbb{E}[I_A] + \mathbb{E}[I_B] - (\mathbb{E}[I_A]\mathbb{E}[I_B] - Cov(I_A, I_B))\\ &= 0.5 + 0.3 - (0.5 \cdot 0.3 - \rho\sigma_{I_A}\sigma{I_B})\\ &= 0.65 - \frac{\sqrt{0.21}}{2 \rho} \end{aligned}P(A or B defaults)​=E[IA​]+E[IB​]−E[IA​IB​]=E[IA​]+E[IB​]−(E[IA​]E[IB​]−Cov(IA​,IB​))=0.5+0.3−(0.5⋅0.3−ρσIA​​σIB​)=0.65−2ρ0.21​​​

Plugging in the bounds of P(A or B defaults)P(\text{A or B defaults})P(A or B defaults), we have ρ∈[−37,37]\rho \in \left[-\sqrt{\tfrac{3}{7}}, \sqrt{\tfrac{3}{7}}\right]ρ∈[−73​​,73​​].

Problem 2. What is the expected number of dice rolls until we get two 666’s in a row? Solution. This is similar to our expected value of HTHTHT problem. Let XXX be a random variable that describes the number of throws to get two sixes in a row. There are three scenarios that we should consider:

Case 1: throwing two consecutive sixes (p=136p = \frac{1}{36}p=361​)
Case 2: throwing a six on the first toss and a different number on the second (p=536p = \frac{5}{36}p=365​)
Case 3: nothing throwing a six on the first toss (p=56p = \frac{5}{6}p=65​)

In Case 1, were are done and our ev is 222. In Case 2, rolling a different number means we’re exactly back where we started and our ev is 2+E[X]2 + \mathbb{E}[X]2+E[X] since we “wasted” our first two throws. In Case 3, we’re back where we started an we’ve only wasted the first throw, giving 1+E[X]1 + \mathbb{E}[X]1+E[X]. Then,

E[X]=136⋅2+536(2+E[X])+56(1+E[X])=4236+3536E[X]\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[X] &= \tfrac{1}{36}\cdot 2 + \tfrac{5}{36}(2 + \mathbb{E}[X]) + \tfrac{5}{6}(1 + \mathbb{E}[X])\\ &= \tfrac{42}{36} + \tfrac{35}{36}\mathbb{E}[X] \end{aligned}E[X]​=361​⋅2+365​(2+E[X])+65​(1+E[X])=3642​+3635​E[X]​

Solving this gives us E[X]=42\mathbb{E}[X] = 42E[X]=42 so we expect to roll 424242 times total in order to get our first string of consecutive 666‘s.

Problem 3. You flip a weighted coin with P(heads)=0.6P(\text{heads}) = 0.6P(heads)=0.6 four times. Every time that a heads is rolled AAA wins $1\$1$1 and every time a tails is flipped, BBB wins $1\$1$1. What is the expected value of a bet where if A wins overall, you get his winnings, if B wins overall you get 0. Solution. This questions is from DRW’s Glassdoor page. It’s a bit unclear what the question means by expected value of a bet so I’ll be solving for the expected value of the game. Additionally, since it doesn’t state what happens if AAA and BBB tie, I’ll be increasing the number of rolls to five. Note that AAA wins if we roll 3,4,53,4,53,4,5 heads and BBB wins if we roll 0,1,20, 1, 20,1,2 heads. Let XXX be a Bernoulli random variable with success being flipping heads (p=0.6p= 0.6p=0.6). Then, XXX follows a binomial distribution and we can caculate the expected value of the game as follows:

E[X]=∑x∈Rxp(x)=∑x=35xb(x;5,0.6)=∑x=35x(nx)px(1−p)5−x=3(53)(0.6)3(0.4)2+4(54)(0.6)4(0.4)1+5(55)(0.5)5≈2.23\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[X] &= \sum_{x\in \mathbb{R}}xp(x) = \sum_{x= 3}^5xb(x; 5, 0.6) = \sum_{x= 3}^5x\binom{n}{x}p^x(1-p)^{5-x}\\ &= 3 \binom{5}{3}(0.6)^3(0.4)^2 + 4 \binom{5}{4}(0.6)^4(0.4)^1 + 5 \binom{5}{5}(0.5)^5\\ &\approx 2.23 \end{aligned}E[X]​=x∈R∑​xp(x)=x=3∑5​xb(x;5,0.6)=x=3∑5​x(xn​)px(1−p)5−x=3(35​)(0.6)3(0.4)2+4(45​)(0.6)4(0.4)1+5(55​)(0.5)5≈2.23​

Then, the expected value of the game is 2.232.232.23, so it would make sense of us to play is so long as our cost of playing is less than $2.23\$2.23$2.23.

Problem 4. You’re presented with two empty jars and 100100100 marbles on a table, 505050 of which are white and the other 505050 are black. You are to put all 100100100 of the marbles into the two jars in any way you choose. I then blindfold you and shakethe jars up to ensure good mixing and rearrange the placing of the jars randomly. You can then request the left-hand jar or the right-hand jar. You get to choose exactly one jar and and can withdraw at most one marble from the jar and you do not get a second chance if you are unhappy with your choice. How many of each color marble should you put in each jar to maximize the probability your blindfolded random draw obtains a white marble? Solution. At first I thought that both jars needed to contain 505050 marbles, in which case it didn’t matter how we distributed the black and white marbles. Due to the mixing and the randomization of which of the two jars you’re picking, you have p=0.5p=0.5p=0.5 of picking either jar. Say you have xxx white marbles in one jar and 50−x50-x50−x in another jar. Then, your probability of picking a white marble is 12⋅x50+12⋅50−x50\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{x}{50} + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{50 - x}{50}21​⋅50x​+21​⋅5050−x​ which gives a 50%50\%50% chance of picking a white marble no matter how you distribute them.

I then realized that we could distribute the marbles however we’d like, meaning that we could keep at little as 000 marbles in one jar and all 100100100 in the other jar. Instead of divising a function to describe how to optimize for this problem I decided to approach it with several cases. We know we have p=12p = \frac{1}{2}p=21​ of choosing either jar. We want to maximize the chance of picking a white marble regardless of which jar you choose. This can be done by placing 111 white marble in the first jar, and the other 999999 marbles in the second jar. This ensures that we have p=12⋅1+12⋅4999≈0.75p = \frac{1}{2} \cdot 1 + \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{49}{99} \approx 0.75p=21​⋅1+21​⋅9949​≈0.75 of picking a white marble. Just testing out some other placements of marbles it’s clear that this is the optimal configuration. Approaching the problem analytically, we simply need to find the maximum of the function

f(x,y)=12⋅xy+12⋅50−x100−yf(x,y) = \tfrac{1}{2} \cdot \tfrac{x}{y} + \tfrac{1}{2} \cdot \tfrac{50 -x}{100 -y}f(x,y)=21​⋅yx​+21​⋅100−y50−x​

where xxx is the number of white marbles we place in the first jar and yyy is the total number of marbles we place in the first jar, which can be done with some multivariable.

Problem 5. I will spin a fair roulette wheel with five sections. Four of the five sections pay 111 and the other pays 555. If the cost is $1.5\$1.5$1.5 per spin should you play the game? What if you can only spin once and the payoffs to enter and cost per spint were multiplied by 100010001000? Solution. This is a really simple EV problem. Let XXX be the payoff of playing the game. Then,

E[X]=45×1+15×5=1.8>1.5\mathbb{E}[X] = \tfrac{4}{5} \times 1 + \tfrac{1}{5} \times 5 = 1.8 > 1.5E[X]=54​×1+51​×5=1.8>1.5

When you have the option of playing as much as you like, it makes sense to play the game as the actual payoff converges to the expected payoff in the long run so we expect to make $0.30\$0.30$0.30 profit every 555 times we play.

If we can only spin once, our EV for the game doesn’t change. However, this scenario guages how risk-averse we might be: 80%80\%80% of the time we expect to lose 505050 cents, and 20%20\%20% of the time we expect to win $3.50\$3.50$3.50 beyond what we spent to play the game. Since the cost of the game is relatively low, I would probably still take the bet. However, when the numbers are factored up by 100010001000, we either have a net loss of $500\$500$500 or net gain of $3500\$3500$3500. While the problems hasn’t changed in nature, the risk of playing the game has increased dramatically, and depending on my initial amount of money, I would be much more cautious when playing.

Day Seven: June 27

Todays problems focus on betting games and expected value.

Problem 1. Suppose there are 111111 pirates who are placing their treasure in a safe. As a democratic group of pirates, they have decided that any majority of the pirates should be able to open the safe. They decide to implement this by placing several locks on the the safe, which all need to be openned to open the safe. Each lock can have multiple keys but each key can only open one lock. What is the smallest number of locks needed to secure the safe in this manner? In addition, how many keys should each pirate carry if each pirate can carry multiple keys? Solution. Note that any combination of 555 pirates should not be able to open the safe. That is, there must be a unique lock for every combination of 555 pirates such that none of these pirates have the key to this lock. Then, there should be a total of (115)=462\binom{11}{5} = 462(511​)=462 locks. Each of these locks should have 666 copies in order maintain the majority criterion and these keys should be evenly distributed between all 111111 pirates, giving us 462⋅611=252\frac{462 \cdot 6}{11} = 25211462⋅6​=252 keys per pirate.

Problem 2. There is a population of ants that for each time period has p=0.2p = 0.2p=0.2 of dying out (E), p=0.5p = 0.5p=0.5 of staying the same (S), and p=0.3p= 0.3p=0.3 of doubling in size. Is the ant population likely to die long term? Solution. This is a spinoff of a question regarding amoeba populations from A Practical Guide. Lets call P(E)P(E)P(E) the probability that the ant population goes extinct. We can break this down into the different conditional probabilities: P(E ∣S)P(E\, | S)P(E∣S), P(E ∣E)P(E\, | E)P(E∣E), and P(E ∣D)P(E\, | D)P(E∣D). P(E ∣ S)=P(E)P(E \, |\, S) = P(E)P(E∣S)=P(E) since the state is the same as the beginning state, P(E ∣ D)=P(E)2P(E\, |\, D) = P(E)^2P(E∣D)=P(E)2 (assuming each additional population of ants is independent to one another) as there are now two populations of ants, and P(E ∣ E)=1P(E \, | \, E) = 1P(E∣E)=1. Then,

P(E)=0.5⋅P(E)+0.3⋅P(E)2+0.2⋅1P(E) = 0.5 \cdot P(E) + 0.3 \cdot P(E)^2 + 0.2 \cdot 1P(E)=0.5⋅P(E)+0.3⋅P(E)2+0.2⋅1

Solving for this gives us that P(E)=23P(E) = \frac{2}{3}P(E)=32​ so it is quite likely the ant population dies out. The question doesn’t clarify what it means to double in size long term and EEE, DDD, and SSS are not collectively exhaustive events so it’s quite tricky to calculate the other two outcomes. One could potentially use a Markov chain to simulate what happens in the future

Problem 3. A gambler starts with an initial fortune of iii dollars. On each successive game, the gambler wins $1\$1$1 white probability ppp, 0<p<10 < p < 10<p<1, or loses $1\$1$1 with probability q=1−pq = 1-pq=1−p. He will stop if he ever accumulates NNN dollars or loses all his money. What is the probability that he will end up with NNN dollars? Solution. This is the gambler’s ruin problem. Let PiP_iPi​ denote the probability that the gambler’s fortune will reach NNN instead of 000 for each initial state 0≤i≤N0 \leq i \leq N0≤i≤N. Note that P)0=0P)0 = 0P)0=0 and PN=1P_N = 1PN​=1. The next after iii is going to be i+i+i+ with probability ppp or i−1i-1i−1 with probability qqq. Then, Pi=pPi+1+qPi−1P_i = pP_{i+1} + qP_{i-1}Pi​=pPi+1​+qPi−1​. As p+q=1p +q =1p+q=1, we have that

Pi+1−Pi=qp(Pi−Pi−1)=(qp)2(Pi−1−Pi−2)=(qp)i(P1−P0)P_{i+1} - P_i = \frac{q}{p}(P_i - P_{i-1}) = \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^2(P_{i-1} - P_{i-2}) = \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^i (P_1 - P_0)Pi+1​−Pi​=pq​(Pi​−Pi−1​)=(pq​)2(Pi−1​−Pi−2​)=(pq​)i(P1​−P0​)

We can then build an expression for PiP_iPi​ from the ground up starting from P2P_2P2​:
P1=pP2+qP0→P2=1pP1=[1+qp]P1P_1 = pP_2 + qP_0 \to P_2 = \frac{1}{p}P_1 = \left[1 + \frac{q}{p}\right]P_1P1​=pP2​+qP0​→P2​=p1​P1​=[1+pq​]P1​
P2=pP3+qP1→P3=1qP2−qpP1=[1+qp+(qp)2]P1P_2 = pP_3 + qP_1 \to P_3 = \frac{1}{q} P_2 - \frac{q}{p}P_1 = \left[1 + \frac{q}{p} + \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^2\right] P_1P2​=pP3​+qP1​→P3​=q1​P2​−pq​P1​=[1+pq​+(pq​)2]P1​
⋯\cdots⋯
Pi=[1+qp+⋯+(qp)i−1]P1P_i = \left[1 + \frac{q}{p} + \cdots + (\frac{q}{p})^{i-1}\right]P_1Pi​=[1+pq​+⋯+(pq​)i−1]P1​ Note that the terms in the brackets is just a finite geometric sum. Applying this to PNP_NPN​,

PN=1=[1+qp+⋯+(qp)N−1]P1={1−(qp)N1−qpP1 if qp≠1NP1 if qp=1P_N = 1 = \left[1 + \frac{q}{p} + \cdots + \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^{N-1}\right]P_1 = \begin{cases} \frac{1- (\frac{q}{p})^N}{1 - \frac{q}{p}}P_1& \text{ if } \frac{q}{p} \neq 1 \\ NP_1& \text{ if } \frac{q}{p} = 1 \end{cases}PN​=1=[1+pq​+⋯+(pq​)N−1]P1​=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​1−pq​1−(pq​)N​P1​NP1​​ if pq​​=1 if pq​=1​

We can manipulate this to solve for PiP_iPi​ through P1P_1P1​:

P1={1−qp1−(qp)NP1 if qp≠11N if qp=1 and Pi={1−(qp)i1−(qp)NP1 if qp≠12iN if qp=12P_1 = \begin{cases} \frac{1- \frac{q}{p}}{1 - \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^N}P_1& \text{ if } \frac{q}{p} \neq 1 \\ \frac{1}{N}& \text{ if } \frac{q}{p} = 1 \end{cases} \text{ and } P_i = \begin{cases} \frac{1- \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^i}{1 - \left(\frac{q}{p}\right)^N}P_1& \text{ if } \frac{q}{p} \neq \frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{i}{N}& \text{ if } \frac{q}{p} = \frac{1}{2} \end{cases}P1​=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​1−(pq​)N1−pq​​P1​N1​​ if pq​​=1 if pq​=1​ and Pi​=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​1−(pq​)N1−(pq​)i​P1​Ni​​ if pq​​=21​ if pq​=21​​

Given even odds of winning and losing each round, our probability of coming out with NNN dollars is proportional to our beginning state. What’s interesting is that even if we decrease the odds of success slightly, say changing it from 12\frac{1}{2}21​ to 3880\frac{38}{80}8038​, there is a drastic decrease in the ability to come out with NNN dollars versus losing everything. I hope to include a Markov chain version of this problem with specific constraints and work through that sometime soon.

Problem 4. Suppose you roll a dice and are paid the value that you roll. If you roll a 5,65,65,6 you can roll again and if you roll 1,2,3,41,2,3,41,2,3,4 the game ends. How much would you pay to play this game? Solution. Let XXX be the payoff of playing this game. There is p=23p = \frac{2}{3}p=32​ that you roll a losing number and your payoff is what you rolled the first round. In this case, our expected value is the average of {1,2,3,4}=52\{1,2,3,4\} = \frac{5}{2}{1,2,3,4}=25​. Also, there is a 13\frac{1}{3}31​ chance where we roll a 555 or a 666 and have the chance to roll again, bringing us back to our initial state. Then, we have

E[X]=23⋅52+13(112+E[X])\mathbb{E}[X] = \frac{2}{3}\cdot \frac{5}{2} + \frac{1}{3}(\frac{11}{2} + \mathbb{E}[X])E[X]=32​⋅25​+31​(211​+E[X])

Solving this gives us E[X]=214\mathbb{E}[X] = \frac{21}{4}E[X]=421​. Then I would pay up to $5.25\$5.25$5.25 to play this game.

Problem 5. Your recruiter loads two bullets separated by one chamber into a 6-chamber revolver. He then spins it,points it at his head and shoots but survives since he fired an empty chamber. You’re given the gun and must fire at your head but you may choose to spin the barrel first or take the shot directly. Unfortunately, another bullet will be loaded into the gun if you decide to spin. Do you spin the barrel? Solution. If we spin, we have a 36\frac{3}{6}63​ chance of dying as we have randomized the location of the next shot relative to the chambers. If we don’t there are five chambers left, two of which have bullets. However, these bullets are staggered by one chamber so the number of configurations of the two bullets is limited. Let’s number the chambers in order from 111 through 666. Let’s say that the bullets are in chambers 111 and 333. Given that your recruiter survived, he must have fired from chambers 2,4,52, 4, 52,4,5 or 666, which occur equally likely. If he fired chamber 222 or 666, then the next shot will have a bullet and if he fired 444 or 555, then the next shot will be safe. Then you have 50%50\%50% chance of dying if we shoot immediately, which is equal to the chance of dying if we decided to spin. Then it does not matter whether we spin or not since we have an equal chance of surviving the next round regardles of how we act.

Bonus. You have xxx red cards and yyy blue cards. I flip them over one at a time. The probability of flipping a particular color is proportional to the amount of those colored cards left. You start with 111 and every flip you can bet some proportion of your money on red or blue. If you win the bet, you gain twice your bet, but if you lose the bet, you gain nothing. What is the strategy that maximizes expectancy and minimizes variance? Solution I’m not counting this problem since I had to search up the solution to this interview question and read it over several times in order to understand what was going on. I’ll be typing up the solution later!

Week One Review

This week, I covered mostly probability games, Markov chains, and some combinatorial brain teasers. I realized that I still have a lot intution to build on how analytically to approach each problem, which I’ll keep in mind in future weeks. I hope to be posting some more challenging problems as well, since the ones I’m currently working on are not overly difficult. Next week I hope to include some topics on options and market making and reviewing some statistics and algorithms to add some variety to the problems I’ve been doing. I’m also doing readings on game theory so hopefully I’ll be able to include some more nuanced questions on winning strategies and other related topics.

Thanks for tuning in and below are a couple of resources that I used this week that might be helpful:

  • A Practical Guide to Quantitative Finance Interviews
  • Quant/FM/Data Science Compilation
  • Linear Algebra, Probability, and Financial Math
  • General Problems & Brain Teasers
  • Heard on the Street: Quantitative Questions from Wall Street Job Interviews

item.title: We Don't Say Love
item.description: A blank verse poem and discussion on filial affection and piety in Chinese culture.
item.content:encoded:
Exploring Unspoken Affection in Asian Communities
May 23, 2020 | Updated May 28, 2020

Welcome to my first (official) blog post! Below is a piece in iambic pentameter blank verse I was working on a while back:

In Chinese, we don’t say love.
instead my mother asks, “ 你 (nǐ) 吃 (chī) 了 (le) 吗 (ma) ”                                 (“have you eaten”)
repeatedly as if I never ate
when I was far from home. She says it like
I’d only miss the warmth of homemade soups
and not the warmth of sitting next to her
on weekend evenings as we watched TV.
In Mandarin, we don’t admit our love.
Instead my mother brought a plate of fruit
up to my room in silence while I slept
before departing home for work each day.
We don’t say love. Instead we might say “ 疼 (téng) ”                  (“to hurt/love fondly”)
as if to note that love inherently
implies self-sacrifice. We might say this,
but never love. For love is too simple
a word. Just two small letters in a row;
a single syllable that manifests
with barely any effort from within.
And love is way too large a word to be
encompassed utterly in a small one.
So in my family, we don’t say love.
Instead, as I depart my room each day
I call my mom to ask, “ 你 (nǐ) 吃 (chī) 了 (le) 吗 (ma) ”

I originally wrote this poem for a class I took to develop my poetry-writing and practice writing in form. Some technical details about this poem: it’s written in iambic pentameter blank verse. I chose this topic to address how love is expressed and perceived in Asian communities. Specifically, I wanted to address the phenomenon that Asian-American families rarely say that they love each other and, more often than not, choose to express themselves through selfless action instead of words.

Growing up, I often struggled to reconcile the two, often opposing sides of my identity. Chinese and American culture disagree fundamentally on issues regarding an individual’s identity and purpose. While one favors creative expression and individualism, the other prioritizes one’s connection and duty to family. Growing up in America and being immersed in American media and education has helped me develop an understanding of my nation and myself. It’s part the experience that drove many of our parents to immigrate to the U.S. in the first place one that has provided many of us with opportunities and freedoms that were unavailable to our parents. Yet this same experience has the power to unequivocally estrange us from our Asian culture and heritage.

And while I’ve come to better understand my identity as a Chinese-American, I sometimes still have trouble internalizing some of the nuances of Chinese culture. This poem is my personal attempt to comment on and appreciate the nuance of love in Chinese culture. While we don’t express it directly through our words, we demonstrate the immensity of our love for one another through the subtle actions and comments that often go unnoticed by each other. As a result, expressing love and appreciation for others has become synonymous with “show don’t tell” in my daily life.

I want to briefly discuss the role of using Chinese phrases and words in this poem as well. Just as words cannot express the depth of the love we feel for our family and friends, I didn’t feel that English was sufficient to communicate just how loudly our actions speak for us. Instead, Chinese characters and phrases, especially ones commonly used to convey love and affection, were better suited for this role. The phrases I chose to use can be translated into English, yet (as Chinese speakers would agree) the connotation of these words are woefully lost in translation. These words in their original form were so much more accurate to my experience than anything I could come up with in English, and I hope they help underscore the uniqueness of the Asian-American experience.

Thanks for tuning in! I’m currently working on setting up a subscription form directly on my website, but please fill out this form if you would like me to add you to the mailing list for the future!

item.title: Welcome to My Website!
item.description: A quick introduction to my blog!
item.content:encoded:
A Brief Intro to My Blog
May 12, 2020

Greetings! This is the first of hopefully many posts that I’ll be uploading onto this platform. This website has been a goal of mine for a while now and the quarantine has given me an opportunity (in my boredom) to finally get on top of it. I’ve been challenging myself recently to write more in an attempt to document my thoughts and become a more mindful person in the process.

I hope to be posting every couple of weeks or so on a variety of topics but primarily on mathematics, poetry, and stand-up, along with general ideas and discussions I find interesting. This will include updates on my research, drafts of poems I’ve been working on, and commentary on current events and pop culture. Hopefully this blog will become a collection of such content that can provide some insight on some of these topics.

Moving Forward

I’ll be posting semi-regularly and adding functionality to this website as I become more comfortable with web development. I’m currently working on setting up a subscription for people who are interested in keeping up with this blog and other details as I decide on where I want to to take this (If you’re interested in subscribing, head over to this form and I will add you to the mailing list after I have it set up). If you’re interested in learning more about me, please feel free to navigate around this site or email me at jerry.qin@vanderbilt.edu. In the meantime, thanks for tuning in and I hope you’ll find some of the content illuminating and thought-provoking.
